Hi Jonas,

I prefer the link element specifically because it's more generic=
. E.g.  
in your example =85

<link rel=3D"orders" type=3D"text/xml" href=
=3D"/api/client/123/orders.xml" />

=85 any piece of client software that u=
nderstands a link element could  
visualize it, e.g. presenting the "rel" a=
nd "type" to the end user.  
Clients that understand links and text/xml (sh=
udder, application/xml)  
could make a little more sense of it. Finally, cl=
ients understanding  
an "orders" relationship could handle _any_ kind of d=
ocument that  
contains links to orders.

In other words, I believe the usu=
al case for a generic approach can be  
made here, especially since the dis=
advantage is really just a matter  
of syntactical details.
